dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere in the depths of the Amazon Rainforest, a home- ROPE BRIDGE stretches across a vast jungle valley. Rainwater cascades down the hillsides in waterfalls and a huge river flows far beneath, but sitting on the bridge, perfectly serene, are two elderly bears, LUCY and PASTUZO Lucy is pouring herself a CUP OF TEA while Pastuzo makes himself a MARMALADE SANDWICH. He puts it under his battered red bush hat for safekeepin and sets about making a quadruple decker sandwich to eat

dialogues.speaker: PASTUZO
dialogues.text: Our last rainy season.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Just think Pastuzo, this time next month we’ll be in London...

dialogues.speaker: PASTUZO
dialogues.text: ..-where the rivers run with marmalade and the streets are paved with bread. Lucy gives him a quizzical look.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Did you read the book about London?

dialogues.speaker: PASTUZO
dialogues.text: I skimmed it.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (gently scolding) Pastuzo!

dialogues.speaker: PASTUZO
dialogues.text: Well, reading makes me sleepy. But any city that can come up with this is alright by me. Pastuzo slaps the last slice of bread onto his sandwich a squishes it down, SQUIRTING MARMALADE over Lucy’s glasses She takes them off to wipe them - but as she does so, she spots something moving in the river beneath them.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Oh Pastuzo, look! Pastuzo picks up a pair of binoculars and peers through t to see a TINY BEAR CUB clinging desperately to a BRANCH, floating inexorably downstream towards a WATERFALL.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 2.

dialogues.speaker: PASTUZO
dialogues.text: It’s... it’s a cub! Pastuzo lowers his binoculars to see Lucy climbing down o of the TRAILING VINES that hang from the rope bridge. PASTUZO (CONT’D) Lucy!

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Lower me down. Pastuzo unties the vine and starts lowering Lucy towards torrent that rages beneath them. Meanwhile, the cub is struggling to stay on his branch. H loses his footing and slips into the water, but just mana to retain his grip. Lucy is still a few metres above the water.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lower, Pastuzo! Lower! The cub looks up to see Lucy on the rope, stretching out paw towards him. It’s his last chance of salvation. He reaches up to grab hold but SLIPS FROM THE BRANCH. Without pausing to think, Lucy DIVES FROM THE VINE and in the swirling WATERS. Pastuzo is YANKED FROM HIS POSITION ON THE BRIDGE, his HA falling from his head. The branch, without its passenger, plunges over the water and disappears into the swirling mists below. Back on the rope bridge, there is no sign of life. But then the camera moves and we discover PASTUZO has man to cling to the underside of the bridge with one paw. He cautiously opens an eye and, to his great relief, sees Lucy swinging from the vine beneath him.

dialogues.speaker: PASTUZO
dialogues.text: Lucy? Lucy!

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I'm afraid we're not going to London after all, Pastuzo.

dialogues.speaker: PASTUZO
dialogues.text: Why not? Lucy is staring with love in her eyes at the drenched lit bear cub she has managed to save from the waters.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 3. PASTUZO’S HAT has fallen onto his head.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: We've got a cub to raise.

dialogues.speaker: PASTUZO
dialogues.text: What’s he like?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Rather small... The CUB SNEEZES, sending PASTUZO’S HAT over his face.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And rather sneezy! Lucy tenderly lifts the hat to discover the cub is now ea PASTUZO’S SANDWICH. He burps, surprising himself.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But he likes his marmalade.

dialogues.speaker: PASTUZO
dialogues.text: Well that’s a good sign.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Oh yes, Pastuzo. If we look after this bear, I have a feeling he’ll go far. As Pastuzo hauls them to safety, the camera cranes up to vast Amazon sky. We mix through to a different sky and the TITLES START as crane down to find the towers, spires and rooftops of the LONDON SKYLINE, a few bear years later...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a beautiful street of pastel coloured homes, the SAME CUB, a little older and scruffier, but still wearing the battered red hat, sits in a round attic window. This is PADDINGTON, gazing out at the city he loves.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Aunt Lucy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington sets about his day.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I hope all is well in the Home for Retired Bears. Life in London has been better than ever this summer.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 4. INT. THE BROWNS’ BATHROOM - MORNING Paddington fires up two ELECTRIC TOOTHBRUSHES.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm really getting to grips with how things work. He puts the two toothbrushes in his EARS. Next he sticks them up his NOSE. And only then does he use them on his TEETH.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And it seems there’s something new to do every day. INT. THE BROWNS’ KITCHEN - MORNING Paddington sits at the table, surrounded by the happy cha of a family breakfast. JUDY, a defiantly intellectual fourteen year old, shows Paddington a leaflet for “KOSLOVA’S STEAM FAIR” while he devours a pile of sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Guess what, Paddington? The Steam Fair's coming to town! I’m going along tonight to write about it for my newspaper. JONATHAN, her twelve year old brother, is immediately concerned at the impact this might have on his reputation

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Who’s going to want to read about that?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Everyone! They travel the world in an old steam train. I thought you’d love it.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I do, but don’t tell anyone ok? Not cool. Judy rolls her eyes at her conformist brother. Their adventurous mother, MARY, is full of the fun of the fair.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why don’t we all go? Your father’s a dab hand at the coconut shy.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 5. Her husband, HENRY, mimes throwing a ball and feels a twi in his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Ooh, not anymore. Coconuts are a young man’s game.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Well I think you’re in great shape for a man of your age, Mr Brown.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Paddington. Hang on, how old do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh... about eighty?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Eighty?!

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: At least! Paddington puts the last sandwich in his hat and gets up leave - but MRS BIRD, the Browns’ aged Scottish relative redoubtable housekeeper, stops him in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BIRD
dialogues.text: Just a minute, wee bear. I thought I told you to clean your ears.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: But I did, Mrs Bird... Mrs Bird MAGICS A COIN from BEHIND HIS EAR. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) I wonder how that got in there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington runs out of the house as a BICYCLE comes round corner towards him.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I really feel at home in Windsor gardens. The FRENCH CYCLIST rings her bell.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Bonjour, Mademoiselle!

dialogues.speaker: CYCLIST
dialogues.text: Good morning, Paddington!  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 6. Paddington leaps on the back of the bike and hands the cyclist a sandwich as they free-wheel down the street.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: I brought you breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: CYCLIST
dialogues.text: Thank you. Your sandwiches always put me in a good mood. They pass an ABSENT-MINDED DOCTOR emerging from his house

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Morning, Dr Jafri. You haven’t forgotten your keys, have you? Dr Jafri stops, pats his pockets and panics.

dialogues.speaker: DR JAFRI
dialogues.text: Keys? Keys! Dr Jafri rushes back to his closing front door, catching just before he is locked out.

dialogues.speaker: DR JAFRI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you, Paddington!

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: You’re welcome! Paddington and the Cyclist ride on past the COLONEL, a gloomy, dishevelled man with a military moustache and a week’s stubble wearing a dressing gown. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Glorious day, Colonel!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Is it? How absolutely thrilling. They pass a NEWSPAPER KIOSK. The owner is a cheery eccent with a twinkle in her eye and a parrot on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: How was your date, Miss Kitts?

dialogues.speaker: MISS KITTS
dialogues.text: Well he wasn’t the one, but you know what they say?

dialogues.speaker: PARROT
dialogues.text: Plenty more fish in the sea.

dialogues.speaker: MISS KITTS
dialogues.text: Exactly! Mrs Kitts THROWS A PAPER towards the bike. Paddington cat it and puts it in the CYCLIST’S BASKET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 7. They sail round a corner and pull alongside a DUSTBIN LOR Paddington hops onto the back of the lorry as the cyclist heads off in another direction.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: (to the Bin Man) Morning, Mr Barnes!

dialogues.speaker: BIN MAN
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Au revoir, Mademoiselle.

dialogues.speaker: CYCLIST
dialogues.text: Bye, Paddington. The Bin Man hands him a much-thumbed A-Z MAP OF LONDON.

dialogues.speaker: BIN MAN
dialogues.text: Come on then, test me.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: What’s the quickest way from Buckingham Palace to Big Ben?

dialogues.speaker: BIN MAN
dialogues.text: Ooh, an easy one! Straight down the Mall, turn right...

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Everyone’s so kind and welcoming, even though they’re very busy. The dustbin lorry passes under a railway bridge as a COLOURFUL TRAIN crosses carrying KOZLOVA’S STEAM FAIR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary DIVES into the LAKE.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mrs Brown has decided to swim to France. It seems an awful lot of hard work given you can go by boat or plane or even train. CUTAWAY: VARIOUS MODES OF TRAVEL.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But she’s spent the summer cooped up illustrating a series of adventure stories and has decided she wants one of her own.  10 11 12 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 8. INT. HENRY AND MARY’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Mary, sitting at her desk, doodles a picture of herself sitting at the same desk. The drawing COMES TO LIFE and ILLUSTRATED MARY climbs out the window. We discover the window is actually in an airs floating over an ocean. ILLUSTRATED MARY dives out of the window and into the wat below, where she discovers a sunken city. INT. JUDY’S BEDROOM - DAY Judy is on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Judy is suffering from a broken heart.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I’m dumped? I think you’1l find you're dumped Tony. She slams down the phone.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Her first reaction was to become a nun - but she soon got over that and has thrown herself into a new hobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy comes into the room and discovers a PRINTING PRESS.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She found an old printing press at school and is starting a newspaper. With no boys. Paddington watches Judy proudly printing the first issue “The Portobello Express”.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Now all we need is some news!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington helps Jonathan put the finishing touches to a scale model of a steam engine.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 9.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jonathan is joining her at big school this year. He spent the summer building a steam engine but I’m not supposed to talk about it as it is ‘not cool’. 13 CUTAWAY: CHANGING LOOK BOOK. A flip-flap book shows Jonathan going from his true self new persona wearing ridiculous cyber-shades.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He’s got a whole new look and if anyone asks, he’s called J-Dog - and is definitely not into steam trains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan sadly shuts the steam engine away in his cupboar

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But Mr Brown has been busiest of all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Brown stands among a crowd of his colleagues, nervousl anticipating the announcement of his promotion.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He recently had a surprise at work. C.E.O. I’m delighted to announce our new Head of Risk Analysis will be... Steve Visby. A MUCH YOUNGER MAN steps forward. Henry’s face drops.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This has triggered what Mrs Bird calls a Full Blown Midlife Crisis. 16 CUTAWAY: FOOD BLENDER, HAIR DYE.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It involves blending his food, painting his hair and engaging in a process called “Chakrabatics.”  17 18 19 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera tracks across a group of lycra-clad young peop doing the splits.

dialogues.speaker: CHAKRABATICS INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: Open your mind and your legs will follow. Henry, similarly dressed, tries to do the splits and fall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington jumps off the dustbin lorry, returning the A-Z

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: That’s ten out of ten, Mr Barnes!

dialogues.speaker: MR BARNES
dialogues.text: Thank you, Paddington.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Keep up the good work! The Bin Lorry drives on as Paddington walks down the mark greeting the market traders.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh Aunt Lucy, you sent me to London to find a home and it’s worked out better than I ever imagined. I have a wonderful family and have made friends in all sorts of places. Paddington stops to give some breakfast to WOLFIE, a stra dog who lives in an alley off the Portobello Road.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Here you go, Wolfie. See you tomorrow!

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I do hope if you could see me, you'd be pleased. Lots of love from Paddington. Paddington walks up the street into GRUBER’S ANTIQUES.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Mr Gruber?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington walks through to the back of the shop where th are boxes and crates full of FAIRGROUND MEMORABILIA.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 11. Mr Gruber is coming downstairs from the upper workshop.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: Ah Mr Brown, come in! I just hada visit from Madame Kozlova who runs the fair.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh yes?

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: They were having a clear out and found all these old crates stuffed with memory-bilia they thought had been lost forever. Paddington growls, interested.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's asked me to sell it for them while they’re in town and I thought there must be something in here for your Aunt Lucy’s birthday.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Good idea. Paddington starts looking through the memorabilia, touchi VAN DER GRAAF GENERATOR which makes his FUR STAND ON END.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: Ooh! Look at this! He pulls out a MECHANICAL MONKEY ON A TRAPEZE.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: It’s very nice, Mr Gruber, but...

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: I know, I know, it’s got to be perfect.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Since Uncle Pastuzo died, I’m the only relative she’s got left - and it isn’t every day a bear turns a hundred. Paddington rummages in a trunk, finding a WIG AND GLASSES

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: Quite so. Ah, how about these rolling shoes? He holds up some ROLLER SKATES. Paddington - now wearing wig and glasses - is unconvinced.  20 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 12.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Please Mr Gruber, be serious.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: Perhaps your Aunty’s rolling days are behind her. Paddington digs into one of the trunks.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: I think you might be right. Ooh. What’s this? He pulls out an OLD BOOK and Mr Gruber consults a list.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: Ah, now this must be the popping book! Very interesting.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: You see, Madame Kozlova’s great- grandmother, who started the fair, was a brilliant artist. Every time they visited a new city, she made a popping book to remember it by, and this is London. Paddington opens the book to reveal a POP-UP TOWER BRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh Mr Gruber it’s wonderful! Aunt Lucy’s always dreamed of coming to London and never had the chance - but if she saw this, it would be like she were finally here... As Paddington gazes into the book, the camera pushes in, and we find ourselves in an INCREDIBLE POP-UP WORLD...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PAPER LANDSCAPE COMES TO LIFE. A PAPER SHIP passes through the bridge and, as the camera swoops in towards i we discover a THREE-DIMENSIONAL AUNT LUCY on board. She waves down to the riverbank where a THREE-DIMENSIONAL PADDINGTON is making his way through a crowd of two- dimensional pop-up people towards the gangplank.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Aunt Lucy! Aunt Lucy!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT LUCY
dialogues.text: Paddington!  21 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 13. The two bears fly into each other’s arms. She holds him t and then looks around in wonder.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Come with me, Aunt Lucy. Paddington takes her paw and leads her on a magical journ through the book. They head into a pop-up underground sta and emerge - via a page turn - in a pop-up Piccadilly Cir PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Well? What do you think

dialogues.speaker: AUNT LUCY
dialogues.text: It’s wonderful! They cross the road towards a pop-up bus and get on board

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: One and a half bears, please.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: Mind your step, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT LUCY
dialogues.text: What a polite young man. Another page turn takes them to St. Paul's Cathedral wher they feed the birds. A pigeon coos pleasantly. AUNT LUCY (CONT’D) What a polite young pigeon! And then, finally, across the river looking at Big Ben. AUNT LUCY (CONT’D) Oh Paddington! You’ve made an old bear so very happy. The BOOK CLOSES and we find ourselves back in the real wo INT. GRUBER’S ANTIQUES - DAY Paddington’s eyes glisten with joy.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: This is perfect. Mr Gruber consults the list in more detail.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: Ah. We have a snag.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Do we?  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 14.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: You see, this popping book is the only one of its kind - and they want rather a lot of money for it. Paddington reaches into his ear and pulls out a coin.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Mrs Bird found this coin in my ear at breakfast. Perhaps there’s more. He starts banging the side of his head, hoping to dislodg more money from his ear.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: It’ll take more than an earful, Mr Brown! I’m afraid you'd need a thousand of those coins.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh. Paddington puts the coin back in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: Take another look at the monkey. I think he’s super-duper. He offers up the mechanical monkey which flies off its st

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can fix that.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: That's very kind, Mr Gruber, but Aunt Lucy did so much for me when I was a cub, and this could be my way of saying thank you. I’m going to get a job and buy that book.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: Well the barber mentioned he was looking for someone to mind his shop this afternoon. Why don’t you try there? 22 EXT. BARBER’S SHOP - DAY PADDINGTON, wearing a barber’s jacket, is sweeping up in smart shop. The owner, MR GIUSEPPE, is leaving.

dialogues.speaker: GIUSEPPE
dialogues.text: Back in a few minutes. Ciao ciao Paddington!

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Ciao ciao Mr Giuseppe!  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 15. 23 INT. BARBER’S SHOP - DAY Alone in the shop, Paddington turns to the broom and addresses it as though it were a customer.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. Welcome to Giuseppe’s Grooming Salon. What can I do for you today, sir? A shave? A light pomade? Or is it just a brush?

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Quick trim please, barber! Paddington looks round to find a CURT CUSTOMER with a MAGNIFICENT MANE OF GREY HAIR has come in to the shop. The Customer has mistaken Paddington for the barber.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: I’m not the Barber. I just tidy up.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: That’s all I want. Tidy up the back and sides, and nothing off the top.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Yes, but...

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: No buts! Come on man, chop chop! The Customer settles down in the chair and closes his eye

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: If you say so, sir. He takes the scissors from his pocket - but he’s not used them and they fly straight out of his paw into the ceilin He looks around for something to use instead of the sciss and spots some ELECTRIC CLIPPERS. He switches them on - but the MOTOR is so strong it makes ARM VIBRATE WILDLY. He manages to grab hold of the clippers with both paws an clasp them to his chest - but they simply make his WHOLE VIBRATE, like a road worker with a JACKHAMMER. He starts to bounce around the room, the LONG FLEX wrappi around his hands and feet, ensnaring him completely. The clippers tear through a display of brushes as the trailing flex starts snagging on various bits of furnitur Luckily, the customer has dropped off to sleep.  24 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 16. Just then a PHONE RINGS. Paddington happens to bounce pas and answers it, flipping it up behind his ear with his mo PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Hello, Giuseppe’s? Oh hello Mr Jameson. Would you mind if I called you back? I think I may be about to shave a customer. Now Paddington finds the clippers heading TOWARDS THE CUSTOMER. He tries to change course but is so bound up in flex that he’s powerless to do anything about it. Millimetres from the customer's head, Paddington’s progre is miraculously arrested. The cord of the clippers has pu taut, saving the Customer in the nick of time. Phew! PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Thank goodness. But then, the tension in the cable pulls the lever on the chair, and the customer’s hair is lowered onto the clippe Paddington yelps as HAIR FLIES EVERYWHERE. And to make things worse, the plug flies out the socket, shoots up to the ceiling fan, and the flex starts being w up around it. Paddington is yanked off his feet. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) I’m just putting you on hold... The fan whips him up and SPINS HIM AROUND at high speed. EXT. BARBER’S SHOP - DAY A MOTHER is giving her son a stern talking-to outside the barber's shop window.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: It’s only a hair cut, Nelson, there’s nothing to be afraid of. Paddington is HURLED from the fan and SPLATS onto the win

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Come in, take a seat.

dialogues.speaker: MUM
dialogues.text: Let’s go somewhere else. He SQUEAKS OFF THE GLASS and lands on the floor with a th  25 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 17. INT. BARBER’S SHOP - DAY Paddington picks himself up off the floor and stares at t damage. The customer has a TEN INCH STRIP shaved into the back of his head like a REVERSE MOHICAN.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Ooh, that’s not good. Paddington tries to put the SHAVED HAIR back on to the customer’s head but, of course, it won’t stick. Then he has an idea. He gets a jar of marmalade from his pocket, opens it, scoops out a pawful and SMEARS MARMALAD all over the Customer’s now-bald patch.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: (half asleep) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Just putting in some product, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: (half asleep) Jolly good. Carry on. A few moments later: Paddington has finished his repair job. Above him, the fa still bound up with flex and SMOKING GENTLY. He raises the customer’s chair and shows him his handiwor

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: All done, sir! I must say it’s come out a lot better than I expected. The Customer wakes, looks in the mirror. The front is fin But when he touches the back of his head, he feels someth weird and then SCRAPES the marmalade off his head.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: What the devil’s this?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Erm. ..Marmalade.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Marmalade?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Hairy marmalade.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Well get it off!  26 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 18.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Yes sir! Right away sir. Paddington LICKS the back of the customer’s head. Just th the Barber comes back to see what he’s doing.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: What is the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: Paddington!

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Mr Giuseppe! I can explain. It’s not as bad as it looks. But just then the fan sparks, the smoke alarm sounds, and sprinklers go off, drenching everyone in the shop.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. KOSLOVA’S STEAM FAIR - DUSK Paddington WRINGS OUT HIS HAT as the Browns and Mrs Bird through the entrance to KOSLOVA’S STEAM FAIR.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Have you ever been fired, Mr Brown?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Well, no, but are you sure you’re ready for the workplace Paddington? It’s a tough, competitive world out there and I worry a kind, good- natured little bear might get trampled underfoot. Paddington takes a bite of a TOFFEE APPLE but it’s so sti he struggles to free his tongue from the sticky apple.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: He’s right, you know. You can’t trust anyone. That’s why I’m doing my newspaper alone.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Darling, is this about Tony?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ok.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 19.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Everything’s about Tony. And the only reason nobody’s helping with your paper is because it’s so lame.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Well at least I’m not pretending to be someone I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Nor am I! G-Man! Jonathan has spotted a similarly dressed group of other k slips on his cyber-shades and fires up an electronic t-sh

dialogues.speaker: CYBER-KID
dialogues.text: J-dog. Spud bounce. They bump fists. Paddington finally manages to pull his tongue from the toffee apple.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: But Aunt Lucy said if you’re kind and polite, the world will be right.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BIRD
dialogues.text: At least someone’s making sense!

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: And you're kind, Mr Brown, and you've made it to the top.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I’m nowhere near the top. I peaked in the middle. Now the hair’s gone grey, the belly’s popped out and I’ve started to creak. They approach a large crowd who burst into applause as a charming, handsome, charismatic actor with dazzling blue hops up onto a small stage. This is PHOENIX BUCHANAN. Behind him stands an old fairground organ emblazoned with legend, “KOZLOVA’S! Where All Your Dreams Come True!”

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Ooh! Doesn't that man live in the big house on the corner?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: It’s Phoenix Buchanan. Judy starts taking photographs with her camera.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Dad's ‘celebrity’ client.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 20.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: He’s one of our Platinum Club members. And a very famous actor.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BIRD
dialogues.text: Hmph. Or used to be. Now he does dog food commercials. Paddington is surprised by her response. Mary explains.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Mrs Bird doesn't like him because he can never remember her name. Phoenix finally quietens the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Thank you! Thank you! Come on now, that’s enough. Alright, little bit more! Honestly, what am I like? I’m at my absolute naughtiest tonight. The audience laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am tickled the deepest shade of shrimp to have been asked here tonight to open this wonderful old steam fair. But you know, when Madame Kozlova created this place all those years ago, she didn’t do it for the likes of me, whatever I am, “Celebrity,” “Star,” hate all that stuff - “West End Legend,” that’s another one. No, she made it for you guys: the ordinary people. So I'd like to ask one of you to come up here and help start things off. Volunteers? Paddington’s arm shoots up.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eeny, meeny, miney... bear! How about the young bear? Yes, why not? Come on up, young ursine! The audience clap as Paddington climbs up on stage. Judy takes more photographs.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Very good. And you are...

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Paddington Brown.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 21.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Of course! You’re my new neighbour! You live with Henry and Mary and Mrs er... fuh nuh nuh. Mrs Bird rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now I suppose you know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh yes, you’re a very famous actor. Phoenix smiles with false humility. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Or used to be. The smile vanishes. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Now you do dog food commercials. The crowd chuckle. Phoenix smiles through gritted teeth.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Well, a man has to eat!

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: What? Dog food? The crowd laugh again. Phoenix forces himself to laugh al

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Very, very funny. Anyway they do say at Kozlova’s, all your dreams come true. If you could have one wish tonight, what would it be?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh that’s easy. I'd like to get my Aunt Lucy a birthday present.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Aw!

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: I’ve got my eye on old pop-up book of London. Made by Madame Kozlova, as it happens. Phoenix’s eyes light up. He’s intrigued but tries to hide PADDINGTON (CONT’D) But it’s rather expensive so I need to get my paws on an awful lot of money.  27 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 22.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Well I’m not sure if we can promise you that, but we can promise you oodles of fun! So if you’1l lend me a paw, I'd like to declare Kozlova’s Steam Fair OPEN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phoenix takes Paddington’s paw and together they PULL A L which starts the FAIRGROUND ORGAN. Paddington stares in awe as thousands of light bulbs burs into life and the magnificent old rides start moving. He is about to go off and explore when Phoenix takes him one side and starts probing him for information.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Young bear! Young bear! A word in your ear. This pop-up book...

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Do you know it?

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: I know of it but I was led to believe it was lost. Where on earth did you find it?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Mr Gruber’s Antique Shop. He’s keeping it to one side for me but I really need a job. I don’t suppose you have any advice, do you?

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Not really, no. I suppose you’1ll just have to... start at the bottom of the ladder and work your way up.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Do you know what, Mr Buchanan? You've just given me a brilliant idea.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Have I?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: I’m going to be a window cleaner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington sets to work. He opens his suitcase, takes out TELESCOPIC LADDER and extends it against the side of a ho Next, he pulls out a COLLAPSIBLE BUCKET and POPS IT OPEN.  28 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 23. He adds a DASH OF SOAP and fills it from an OUTSIDE TAP. He tries to CLIMB THE LADDER with the bucket - but the bu is so heavy he CAN'T LIFT IT OFF THE FLOOR. He has an idea. He gets a LENGTH OF ROPE out of his suitc and ties one end to the bucket. Next he CLIMBS THE LADDER, feeds the rope through a DRAIN attached to the wall, closes his eyes and JUMPS OFF. But he’s not heavy enough - and opens his eyes to find himself dangling in space. He looks around, wondering how to make himself heavier.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Erm... Ah! He spots a flowerpot on the window ledge and grabs it. His weight is now just enough to raise the bucket up and lower him to the ground. Delighted with his success, he puts the flowerpot down. Unfortunately, of course, the pot was the only thing maki Paddington heavier than the bucket three storeys above. And so, to his surprise, PADDINGTON finds himself RISING the building as the BUCKET DESCENDS. He ends up DANGLING from the top of the building while th floors below, the BUCKET HITS THE FLOOR. As it lands, SOME OF THE WATER SLOSHES OUT. Unfortunately that means Paddington is now MUCH HEAVIER THAN THE BUCKET He DESCENDS - fast - and LANDS IN A HEAP on the floor. Dazed, he lets go of the rope so the BUCKET - and all its soapy contents - PLUMMETS onto the unfortunate bear's HEA The bucket seems to be stuck fast. Dazed, he staggers off around the corner, covered in soap the bucket still firmly wedged on his head. INT. DR JAFRI’S HOME OFFICE - MORNING DR JAFRI is doing some paperwork at his desk. Behind him, through the French Windows, we can see a very soapy bear staggering through the garden. Dr Jafri looks up as Paddington BUMPS INTO THE FRENCH WINDOWS, the impact finally sending the bucket flying off  29 30 31 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 24. Paddington sees Dr Jafri, staring at him. Trying to cover up his mistake, he starts POLISHING THE WINDOWS WITH HIS FUR, using himself as a CHAMOIS LEATHER. Dr Jafri watches as Paddington smears soap on the window his belly then wipes the windows with his back. They are now sparkling. And the doctor is delighted. INT. PADDINGTON’S ATTIC ROOM - DAY Paddington puts his first coins in a HUGE JAR. On it is a label - “AUNT LUCY’S BIRTHDAY FUND”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME-LAPSE of Paddington cleaning all the windows along t street. He ends up at the Colonel’s where he rings the be

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Window cleaner!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Are you sure, Colonel? They’re awfully dirty.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t care and I’m not paying.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: (to himself) Perhaps I‘1l clean them anyway. INT. COLONEL’S HOUSE - DAY The Colonel drinks tea in his gloomy living room. Suddenly he feels a warm light on his face. He looks up to see Paddington cleaning the window, sunlig washing into the room for the first time in years. He goes to the window and looks out. Miss Kitts waves to from the news stand. He tentatively waves back. She does a mime for his entertainment, pretending to go i the basement of the kiosk. He reciprocates by miming bein an elevator. They laugh, a connection beginning to form.  32 33 34 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 25. Suddenly the mood is shattered by a rap at the door. The Colonel opens it to find MR CURRY wearing a HI-VIZ JACKET HAT, a megaphone attached to his belt.

dialogues.speaker: MR CURRY
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Colonel. Are you aware there’s a bear on your roof?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Yes, he’s cleaning my windows.

dialogues.speaker: MR CURRY
dialogues.text: Well it’s not for me to say, sir, but I wouldn’t care to have an undesirable crawling all over my roof - and as Commander of your Community Defence Force--

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Is that an official position, Mr Curry? Or have you just got yourself a yellow coat? He slams the door in Mr Curry’s face. INT. PADDINGTON’S ATTIC ROOM - VARIOUS DAYS (MONTAGE) A sequence of jump cuts shows coins going into the HUGE J on different days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Paddington cleans Wolfie who has never looked better. - Paddington washes the windscreen of the dustbin lorry, clinging onto the wipers. The BINMAN reads his A-Z inside - Paddington in scuba gear squeegees the inside of an aquarium. He waves to the CYCLIST who works there. - Henry, at work in a high office, is startled to see Paddington cleaning the window. - Pull back to reveal he’s cleaning the whole of the Shar CALYPSO BAND are in the Gondola, playing as the song ends EXT. GRUBER’S ANTIQUES - NIGHT Paddington walks home past Mr Gruber’s as a distant clock chimes four. He stops and peers through the window at the pop-up book glass case and smiles to himself.  35 36 37 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 26.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: One more day, Aunt Lucy. But just then he hears the sound of BREAKING GLASS. He goes round to the alley next to the shop and spots a SHADOWY FIGURE climbing through a second floor window. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Mr Gruber?! Startled, the figure turns to reveal he’s a BEARDED THIEF

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: You-- You’re not Mr Gruber!

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: Lorks! The thief climbs through the window, but Paddington sets in pursuit. He runs to the window and winds up his ladder

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh no you don’t! INT. GRUBER’S ANTIQUES - NIGHT The thief runs downstairs, smashes the display case containing the pop-up book and grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington tumbles through the window into Mr Gruber's workshop - but suddenly the BURGLAR ALARM shrieks into li Paddington goes to the window and sees the thief BURST OU THE FRONT DOOR and down the road CARRYING THE POP-UP BOOK

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Stop! Thief!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington careers down the stairs and out of the shop.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Come back with that book!  38 39 40 4l 42 43 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POLICE CAR pulls up at the top of Portobello Road as Paddington bolts down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A serious-minded POLICEWOMAN grabs the radio.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEWOMAN
dialogues.text: Robbery in progress at Gruber's Antiques. Suspect is a small bear in a red hat and a duffle coat! She gets out and gives chase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington chases the thief down an alley towards the can

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington emerges from the alley onto the towpath. He lo around and sees the thief taking a bicycle from on top of canal boat and cycling away. Paddington puts his paw in his mouth and WHISTLES!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolfie pricks up his ears and runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington emerges from a tunnel RIDING THE DOG LIKE A HO galloping after the thief - who has the book in a PANIER the back of his bicycle. Paddington pulls alongside the bicycle and reaches for th book. But just as he takes it, the thief notices what is going on and grabs the book before Paddington can get awa The pair tussle for the book - but suddenly, the thief VE OFF up an incline and across a BRIDGE AHEAD OF PADDINGTON The pair of them are now on different sides of the canal they head to the basin. And the thief is pulling away. But Paddington isn’t done yet. He spurs the dog into life They LEAP UP onto the ROOF OF A BOAT moored by the towpat and JUMP ONTO AN ISLAND in the middle of the canal basin.  44 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 28. They crash through the undergrowth. Ducks, geese and othe birds fly up in to the air, squawking wildly.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Excuse me! Coming through! Who are you?! The thief looks round to see PADDINGTON EMERGE from the undergrowth HANGING FROM THE LEGS OF A SWAN.

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: Strike a light! Amazed by the sight, he LOSES CONTROL OF THE BIKE, and fa off as it goes in the water. High above, hanging from the swan, Paddington watches the thief get to his feet and run off the canal.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: That book is reserved for Aunt Lucy! Oh er, hello there. The swan has looked round and starts pecking at Paddingto PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Ooh! Ow! Not the snout! Help Wolfie! Paddington lets go and falls to the towpath beneath. Fortunately, he lands on the back of the dog and together they race once more after the thief. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Thank you, Wolfie! Attaboy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington follows the thief towards the newspaper kiosk. The thief stops as he hears a police sirens heading towar him from the other direction. Cornered, he raises his hands, still holding the pop-up b

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: (breathless) Alright, alright! You got me. Paddington gets off the dog and walks towards him.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Hand over the book!

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: ‘Fraid I can’t do that. Cheerio.  45 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 29. The thief turns and then suddenly... POOF! He quite literally DISAPPEARS IN A PUFF OF SMOKE.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: But... where did he go? Paddington looks around, astounded, as police cars close from all directions - and then hears a voice behind him.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEWOMAN
dialogues.text: Hold it right there!

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh, thank goodness you’re here!

dialogues.speaker: POLICEWOMAN
dialogues.text: Put your... paws in the air. Paddington lifts his paws in the air.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: But... I’m not the thief! I was chasing the thief and then he...

dialogues.speaker: POLICEWOMAN
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Disappeared in a puff of smoke?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Well... yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington’s friends and neighbours come to their windows the Policewoman leads him up the street in HANDCUFFS. The little bear hangs his head in shame. The Browns run out of their house, frantic, but a Policem holds them back.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Paddington!

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Please, there must be a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: No mistake sir.

dialogues.speaker: MRS BIRD
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Caught red-handed robbing Gruber’s Antiques.  46 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 30.

dialogues.speaker: MR CURRY
dialogues.text: Well, well, well. The truth is out. We opened our hearts to that bear, we opened our doors - well, you did, I kept mine triple locked in accordance with the guidelines - and all along he was robbing you blind. I hate to say I told you so, but I did definitely tell you so. The neighbours mutter to each other. Can this be true? The door of the police van is SLAMMED SHUT. Paddington is driven away, his little face pressed agains the barred rear window, a picture of fear and shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BEARDED THIEF sits in front of a theatrical MAKE-UP MIRROR. He talks to himself in a gruff London accent.

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: A nice little haul, and no mistake. The Thief PULLS AT HIS NOSE - and it PEELS OFF HIS FACE. EYEBROWS follow, and finally his BEARD.

dialogues.speaker: THIEF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Turned out to be quite a stroke of luck, that bear turning up when he did. Coppers think he done it, and we're in the clear. His WIG comes off to reveal the Thief is PHOENIX IN DISGU

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Indeed, Magwich. We gave quite a performance, you and I. Just like the old days. Phoenix catches sight of a COSTUMED MANNEQUIN in the mirr dressed like Hamlet with a skull in one hand.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why the lemon face, Hamlet? If you have something to say, please, share it with us all. Phoenix stands and we find the room is full of MANNEQUINS all the great characters he has played over the years. He walks among them, addressing them as if they were real.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX AS HAMLET
dialogues.text: It is not nor it cannot come to good.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 31.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Oh really, you and your dreary conscience. Tell me this. What would you prefer? That you sit here, gathering dust, while I humiliate myself in a spaniel costume on the television - or that we all return in glory with the greatest one man show the West End has ever seen? The sound of an enormous audience applauding floats throu Phoenix’s mind as he imagines himself lapping up praise.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know what you’re thinking, Scrooge, it’1ll cost a fortune, but if I’m right, that’s exactly what this book will provide. This is no dusty old antique. Hidden on every page, a little lady, pointing to a clue. Find all the clues, we're rich again, and our dog food days are done...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SILVER CLOCHE sits on a linen clothed table. A BUTLER'S HAND removes the cover - to reveal a GILT DOG FOOD BOWL.

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: Dinner is served, master. We pull out to reveal Phoenix dressed in a DOG SUIT.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Thank you, Simpkins. Phoenix turns and speaks to camera.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If, like me, your dog likes to maintain standards, may I recommend Harley's Gourmet din-dins? More taste, more goodness, more - dare I say - class? He puts a forkful of dog food into his mouth and struggle pull a contended expression.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mmm! Woof!

dialogues.speaker: VOICEOVER
dialogues.text: Harley's Gourmet Dog Food. Not to be consumed by humans.  48 49 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various legal types walk towards a courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington stands alone in the dock, confused and afraid. Browns and his friends are all in attendance.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK OF COURT
dialogues.text: All rise!

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: (to himself) Deep breath, Paddington. Remember what Mr Brown said. You’re young, you've done nothing wrong, you'll be fine - so long as you get a fair- minded judge.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Order! Order! But he looks up to see the judge is the same man from the barber’s shop - and he’s monumentally annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh dear.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: We will now hear the case of the Crown versus Paddington Brown. First, MR GRUBER gives evidence.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: ...oh yes, he loved the book. He had set his heart on top of it.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: So you discussed how expensive it was?

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: Yes, but he was raising the money! I refuse to believe young Mr Brown would ever burglarize my shop. Paddington is delighted to see his friend stand up for hi Next, a FORENSIC INVESTIGATOR is on the stand. He gesture a plan of Gruber’s Antiques.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 33.

dialogues.speaker: FORENSIC INVESTIGATOR
dialogues.text: Paw-prints were found here, here, and here, and a substance, later identified as marmalade, was found here. The Prosecutor produces a jar of Paddington’s marmalade.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: And is this the same marmalade? The Forensic Investigator dips his finger in the jar and it around his gums, like a cop testing for cocaine.

dialogues.speaker: FORENSIC INVESTIGATOR
dialogues.text: Yes it is. The court gasp, the tide starting to turn against Padding

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. She steps away with the jar, but the Forensic Investigato snatches it off her and starts eating more marmalade.

dialogues.speaker: FORENSIC INVESTIGATOR
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. (off her look) This evidence is very more-ish. Finally, PHOENIX takes the stand.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK OF COURT
dialogues.text: Phoenix Buchanan, do you swear to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth?

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: May my entrails be plucked forth and wound about my neck should I deceive, I do. Prison is no laughing matter. And I should know. I spent three years in Les Miserables. The court laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: Mr Buchanan, you live on the same street as the defendant.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Yes, I have known the family for years. Henry and Mary and the unforgettable Mrs Fuh nuh nuh. Mrs Bird rolls her eyes.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 34.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: And you were an eye-witness to the events that night.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Indeed I was. Everyone leans forward, keen to hear what he has to say.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was up late writing my one man show when I became aware of a hullaballoo in the street below. I went to my awards room, which is a large room overlooking the kiosk, and I saw young Paddington riding a rather disreputable looking hound. The Prosecutor produces a PENCIL DRAWING of the thief.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: Mary Brown drew this based on the bear's description of the man he claims he was chasing. Phoenix looks admiringly at the face in the picture.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Ooh, handsome devil, isn’t he? Strong cheekbones, noble forehead, dazzling eyes...

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: Yes but did you see him? Your answer will tell us whether the bear is guilty. Did you see this man? Paddington leans forward, desperate to be cleared.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Alas... I did not. The court descends into uproar. The Browns despair.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But perhaps he had already vanished! I beg you, go easy on him. He is but a cub. Alone in the dock, Paddington has lost all hope.

dialogues.speaker: MATCH CUT TO
dialogues.text: 50 51 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington stands behind a BARRED DOOR wearing a GREY STR PRISON UNIFORM and hat. He carries a ROLLED BLANKET. A STERN WARDEN addresses him.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Paddington Brown. Ten years for Grand Theft...

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh, but I never...

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: And Grievous Barberly Harm. Paddington growls, unable to argue with that one.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Follow me. A buzzer sounds. The barred door SLIDES OPEN. SAD CALYPSO MUSIC plays as Paddington follows a Warden anxiously into the HIGH PRISON ATRIUM and up a staircase. There, in the Atrium, are the Calypso Band, wearing priso uniforms and singing a jailhouse lament. The Warden unlocks a cell door and Paddington steps insid

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Mrs Brown usually reads me a story before bed. I don’t suppose...

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Sorry, son. No bedtime stories in here. The Warden slams the door shut behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington climbs up to a pipe under the window, and star to write a letter.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Aunt Lucy. A great deal has happened since I last wrote. I’m afraid there’s been a bit of a mix up with your present and the upshot is I’ve had to leave Windsor Gardens and move... somewhere else. He finds he can’t quite bring himself to tell Aunt Lucy t truth, so tries to put a positive spin on things.  52 53 54 55 56 57 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 36. As he writes, the camera pulls away from the cell window reveal his is one of dozens in a vast, imposing building.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s not quite as charming as the Browns’ house but it’s not all bad. It’s a period property - in fact, it’s one of the most substantial Victorian buildings in London - and the security arrangements are second to none. A searchlight sweeps across walls topped with barbed wire

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: I’m only allowed to see the Browns once a month. I wonder what they’re doing now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary puts up her drawing on a cork board, the start of wh will become her CRIME WALL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry surrounded by text books, looking exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy prints a newspaper. INT. JONATHAN’S ROOM - NIGHT (MONTAGE) Jonathan puts up a poster: Have you seen this man? INT. THE BROWNS’ HALLWAY - NIGHT (MONTAGE) Mrs Bird is standing at the foot of the stairs reading a called “VANISHING ACTS AND HOW TO DO THEM”. Using a washing up brush like a wand, she vanishes a turn and looks around, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington gazes out of the window, his eyes full of tear

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I do hope they don’t forget me. He scrubs this last sentence out, pulling himself togethe  58 59 60 61 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 37.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Of course they won’t. These are the Browns you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They'll sort everything out and I’ll be able to go home and get your present and everything will be right as rain. (to himself) I just need to hold on until then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The iconic landmark silhouetted against the night sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A whistling SECURITY GUARD walks past VARIOUS ROYAL SUITS ARMOUR on display in front of a large, Gothic window. As soon as the guard has left the room, one of the suits MOVES, lifting up its visor to reveal Phoenix. He runs clanking out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still wearing the armour, Phoenix climbs out of a window clanks along the elevated walkway above the bridge to the COAT OF ARMS in the middle. The Thames swirls below. Phoenix takes a closer look at t back of the crest and spots a letter carved into the ston

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: “Dp”. The hunt begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Warden is doing morning roll call.
Paddington emerges from his cell and takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: (to himself) Here goes, Paddington. Manners. Paddington and the other prisoners file out of their cell  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 38. As he approaches the central stairs, Paddington comes fac face with a TATTOOED PRISONER, T-BONE. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Good morning. How would you like to start a gardening club?

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: How would you like to be buried in a very deep hole? Paddington wouldn’t like that at all so falls silent. The pass the Warden, who gives them their jobs as they go.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Brown, P. Laundry Duty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOUR INDUSTRIAL WASHING MACHINES dominate a basement laun labelled “BEDDING”, “TOWELS”, “UNIFORMS”, “COLOURS”. Paddington looks around, trying to find the laundry.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Laundry. Laundry... laundry... Ah! Laundry. Paddington spots a button on the wall marked “Laundry.” A distant mechanical clanking suggests activity, but only after a few seconds does Paddington spot the hatch above He looks up just as the hatch opens, covering him in an AVALANCHE OF CLOTHES. He emerges from the pile, hiccups, and pulls a SINGLE RED SOCK from his mouth. Horrified, he throws the sock away, but it lands on his h Paddington sets about loading the machines and starting t He takes off his own clothes, throws them into the UNIFOR MACHINE and starts it. Pleased with his work, he turns aw then freezes as he remembers something. He turns slowly back to the machine to see the SINGLE RED SOCK in the uniforms wash. He TRIES TO OPEN THE DOOR but it is locked. He heaves on handle with all his might - but it SNAPS OFF. He stares into the window of the washing machine, the wat turning an OMINOUS PINK.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 39. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) (to himself) Oh it’s only one red sock. What’s the worst that could happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room of hardened prisoners, all wearing BRIGHT PINK UNIFORMS, glare fiercely at Paddington.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Afternoon chaps. If you ask me, the pink really brightens the place up a bit.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: If you ask me, you should pipe down and eat your dinner, ‘cos it might be your last. Paddington gulps.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Ok. He walks towards the tables, his tray RATTLING IN FEAR. He sits at a vacant spot, doffs his hat to the prisoners either side, then looks at the DISGUSTING SLOP on his pla He lifts a spoonful to his nose and sniffs. It’s bad. A friendly looking Australian prisoner smiles encouraging

dialogues.speaker: PHIBS
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I used to be a restaurant critic. It’s not as bad as it looks.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh. Paddington eats a spoonful - and sicks up into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: PHIBS
dialogues.text: -..it’s worse.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: What is this? Spoon, a wise, worldly man who’s seen it all before, lean over. He is making a MODEL OF A WINDMILL with matchsticks

dialogues.speaker: SPOON
dialogues.text: Nobody knows. An Old West Country prisoner with a moustache pipes up.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 40.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER JACK
dialogues.text: But we've been eating it three times a day for the last ten years.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Why doesn’t someone have a word with the chef? A dozy looking prisoner, THE PROFESSOR, drops his mug.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: With Knuckles?

dialogues.speaker: SPOON
dialogues.text: Two things to remember if you want to survive in here. Keep your head down, and never talk to Knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Thank you. A quiet prisoner, CHARLEY RUMBLE, GROWLS in agreement - b devious plan has occurred to T-Bone.

dialogues.speaker: T-BONE
dialogues.text: Well I think it’s a great idea. Tell you what son, you get Knuckles to change the menu, and we might forget about you making us look like a bunch of pink flamingos. Paddington is delighted at the prospect of making peace.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Alright then, I will. He looks round at the chef, a mountain of a man in a STRI CHEF’S APRON and HAT, his back turned towards us. Undeterred, Paddington gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: PHIBS
dialogues.text: Mate, I really wouldn’t...

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Aunt Lucy said if you look for the good in people, you'll find it. The other prisoners watch as he walks over to the counter

dialogues.speaker: SPOON
dialogues.text: She obviously never met Knuckles. The Prisoners go quiet as Paddington reaches Knuckles. He raps on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Erm, excuse me, Mr Knuckles?  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 41. Knuckles turns to reveal a huge, granite-faced bruiser. T is a man who has faced a thousand enemies and defeated th all except, perhaps, himself.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Yes? The Warden whispers nervously into his radio.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Send a medic to the canteen.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: I... just wondered if I could have a quick word about the food?

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: You want to complain?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I- I wouldn’t say complain.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: That’s a shame. Because I just love it when people complain. Knuckles’ huge fist closes around a wooden ROLLING PIN on counter - but Paddington doesn’t detect the threat.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Really? Oh! Well in that case, it’s very gritty. And lumpy. And as for the bread... He picks up a baguette and bonks it against Knuckles’ hea knocking his hat askew. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Need I say more? I think we need to completely overhaul the menu. Now I know we’re working to a tight budget but we could at least add some sauce. He picks up a bottle of ketchup and accidentally squirts onto Knuckles’ apron. Knuckles slowly looks down. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Oops. Sorry about that I’1l just... He tries to wipe it off but the stain just spreads. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) No that’s just rubbing it in. Don’t worry. I know what gets ketchup stains out.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 42. He picks up a mustard bottle, squirts some onto the stain then immediately has second thoughts. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Hang on, was it mustard? (he tries wiping) Mmm no. That’s just made it worse! Does anyone know what works on ketchup? He turns to the other prisoners - to find they are all HI UNDER THEIR TABLES. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Chaps?

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Forget the medic. The penny slowly drops as Paddington turns back to Knuckl who SNAPS THE ROLLING PIN IN TWO. WARDEN (CONT’D) Better send a priest. Knuckles GRABS PADDINGTON and LIFTS HIM OFF THE COUNTER.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Now you listen to me, you little maggot!

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Listening.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Nobody criticises my food.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Nobody squirts condiments on my apron.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Nobody bonks me on the head with a baguette!

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: No bonking.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: I‘1l overhaul the menu alright.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 43.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Dish of the day?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Bear pie.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: I don’t like it! Paddington takes his SANDWICH out of his HAT and PUSHES I INTO KNUCKLES' MOUTH - and shuts his eyes, awaiting the e But Knuckles CHEWS. And astonishment creeps across his fa

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: It's a marmalade sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Marmalade?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: My Aunt Lucy taught me to make it. Knuckles lowers Paddington onto the counter as he eats.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: You mean... you can make this?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Well... yes.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Stand aside. Paddington nods. Knuckles makes a declaration to the room KNUCKLES (CONT’D) Get off the floor, you bunch of yellow-bellies and listen to me! This bear is now under my protection. Anyone touches a hair on his back’1l answer to Knuckles McGinty. That’s Knuckles with a capital ‘N’. Knuckles brandishes his fists. Across eight knuckles are letters of his name: NUCKEL’S. T-Bone is frustrated that his plan has been thwarted.  64 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr McGinty.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Don’t thank me yet. I don’t do nuthin’ for no one for nuthin’.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: You get my protection - so long as you make that marmalade. Deal?
Knuckles SPITS ON HIS HAND and proffers it to Paddington. Paddington, puzzled, SPITS ON KNUCKLES’ HAND TOO.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Deal. INT. GRUBER’S ANTIQUES - DAY Mary is putting up a poster in Mr Gruber’s window.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Somebody's got to recognise him sooner or later.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: (in his own world) Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Are you alright Mr Gruber?

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: Oh I’m probably just being a nincompoop...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: There’s something about this whole business that’s been tickling my brain-box.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh yes? She picks up a pad, takes a pen out of her hair and licks

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: Let me take you back to the night of the robbery. When young Mr Brown called out, the thief took to his heels and ran downstairs...  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 45. As Mr Gruber talks, an animation of Mary’s ILLUSTRATION O THE THIEF appears in the shop.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: ..-and went straight through the front doors, setting off the alarm. The Illustrated Thief grabs the book and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: MR GRUBER
dialogues.text: Ah, but he didn’t go straight through the doors! He came all the way over here to get the popping book. Why not some jewellery or a vase? He can’t have known much about antiques.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Or maybe he knew something about that book that we don’t... 65 EXT. KOSLOVA’S STEAM FAIR - NIGHT The Browns are talking to the OWNER OF THE FAIRGROUND, a colourfully-dressed Russian who works as the FORTUNE TELL

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You may find this hard to believe, Madame Koslova, but Paddington is innocent - and we think the real thief may have broken in just to take that book.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KOZLOVA
dialogues.text: The pop-up book?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: We know it sounds far-fetched...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But anything you could tell us about it could be useful.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KOZLOVA
dialogues.text: There’s quite a story.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Really? Mary is fascinated, Henry skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KOZLOVA
dialogues.text: Come with me I’1l show you where it all happened. You see, my Great-— Grandmother, who started this fair, was the greatest show-woman of her generation. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 67 68 69 70 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 46.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KOZLOVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She could tame lions, breathe fire, swallow swords, but she was most famous for the trapeze. As Madame Kozlova walks up to the Spiegeltent, the camera pushes inside, where we find ourselves in the 1930s...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd of people watch MADAME KOZLOVA perform above them

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KOZLOVA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They called her the Flying Swan. Wherever she went, she was showered with gifts, and made a fortune. As Madame Kozlova takes the applause, people throw flower One RICH MAN in a fur cape tosses her a DIAMOND NECKLACE.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KOZLOVA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But where there is a fortune, there is also jealousy. In the wings stands a MAGICIAN, watching on enviously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Spiegeltent is empty. The Magician stands by the trap ropes, filing through them.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KOZLOVA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The magician wanted it for himself, so one night he cut through the ropes - and the Flying Swan became the Dying Swan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Kozlova is performing her act when the rope snaps and she PLUMMETS TO THE FLOOR. The Magician rushes over to where she lies, pretending to concerned, but surreptitiously pulls a KEY CHAIN from aro her neck - and slips away through the crowd. EXT. MADAME KOZLOVA’S CARAVAN - NIGHT (FLASHBACK) The Magician darts up the steps into the painted wagon. INT. MADAME KOZLOVA’S CARAVAN - NIGHT (FLASHBACK) The Magician uses the key to open the strong box.  71 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 47.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KOZLOVA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He went to her caravan and opened her strong box - but instead of her treasure, all he found was a pop-up book: Twelve Landmarks of London. He leafs through the pop-up book, baffled. Suddenly, a STAGE HAND bursts in with a couple of POLICEM The rest of the fairground workers aren’t far behind.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME KOZLOVA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They had him cornered - but he disappeared in a puff of smoke, and neither he, nor the treasure, were ever seen again. Suddenly, just like Phoenix in Windsor Gardens, the magic disappears in a PUFF OF SMOKE, leaving the book behind. INT. HENRY AND MARY’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Mary is sitting on the bed, Henry is out of sight in thei suite bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I knew there was something special about that pop-up book.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hm?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why else would she have kept it in her strong box? Henry emerges from the bathroom in a BLUE FACE MASK.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're not telling me you believed all that guff are you? He starts rubbing it off.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Madame Koslova drew twelve London landmarks in that book. Well what if they’re not just landmarks. What if they’re... I don’t know, clues?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Clues?!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: To where she hid her fortune!  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You mean... a treasure map?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Exactly! Henry turns away, rolling his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that’s why the thief took it from Mr Gruber’s. First thing tomorrow we need to go every landmark in that pop-up book, see if we can sniff out anything suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Too many adventure stories Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: She’s a fortune teller! She spun you a yarn. It’s what they do.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Honestly darling, you’re so close- minded these days.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: What’s that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What happened to the man I married? He’d have believed me. Henry checks his crow’s feet in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Oh him! He’s gone Mary. I’m afraid your husband's just a creaky old man, not Bullseye Brown. 48. Henry looks in the mirror and imagines himself back in hi heyday, standing at a COCONUT SHY. He throws a ball and knocks over three different coconuts

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG HENRY
dialogues.text: Bullseye.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MARY
dialogues.text: Oh Henry!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Henry? Henry!  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 49. Henry snaps out of his reverie and picks up a poster.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: But the point is we’re not going to help Paddington by going on a wild goose chase. We’re looking for this scruffy chancer, not some swashbuckling pirate hunting for buried treasure. Mary stares at the poster, her theory taking shape.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well I think there’s more to him than meets the eye... 72 INT. PHOENIX’S ATTIC ROOM - NIGHT Phoenix sits at his make-up mirror, readying himself for new disguise.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I think he somehow knew the story of the Koslova fortune and is out there now, trying to find it... Phoenix looks up at an OLD PHOTOGRAPH OF THE MAGICIAN fro Madame Kozlova’s story.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX
dialogues.text: Well, grandfather, tonight we take another step closer. The setting, St. Paul’s Cathedral. The pop-up book stands on the dressing table, open at St. Paul’s Cathedral.

dialogues.speaker: MATCH CUT TO
dialogues.text: 73 EXT. ST. PAUL’S CATHEDRAL - NIGHT A flock of nuns process up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: PHOENIX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But how to enter unobserved? Enter Sister Agatha... 74 INT. ST. PAUL’S CATHEDRAL - NIGHT The nuns process through the cathedral. One of them is PHOENIX, DISGUISED IN A HABIT. He ducks out of the procession and slips into a staircase his habit covering the camera and taking us into darkness  75 76 Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 50. INT. PADDINGTON’S CELL - NIGHT In the darkness, we hear a voice.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Wakey wakey. Paddington opens his eyes to find Knuckles inches from hi nose. Thunder crashes in the distance. KNUCKLES (CONT’D) Marmalade time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Warden lets Paddington and Knuckles into the canteen, locking the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Um... Mr McGinty? Mr McGinty?

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Well, the thing is, I’m actually innocent.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Ha!

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: And I wondered if you had any advice on how to clear my name? Now that we’re friends...

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Friends? I’m your boss, not your buddy.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, after you. Paddington holds the kitchen door open for Knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: (suspicious) Why? So you can stab me in the back?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: No. Because it's polite! Aunt Lucy said if you’re kind and polite, the world will be right.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 51.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: You were ahead of me, now you’re behind. That makes you a sap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paddington follows him in to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Ingredients are over there. He nods over to some shelves and flops into a chair.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Erm... aren’t you going to help?

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Nope. Now get on with it.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: But there’s five hundred hungry prisoners coming for breakfast so I’1l need a thousand juicy oranges--

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: And rule number one: no talking. He opens a prison newspaper: The Hard Times. Paddington starts HUMMING as he puts on his STRIPED APRON picks up a CHEF’S HAT. Knuckles slowly lowers his paper. KNUCKLES (CONT’D) Rule number two. No humming, or singing or any other expressions of bonhomie. Paddington nods, wanting to stay on the right side of him Knuckles raises his paper and for two seconds, there’s pe But then he hears a STRAINING, HEAVING NOISE. Knuckles lowers his paper and looks over to see Paddingto trying to heave a LARGE SACK OF ORANGES off a high shelf.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Ooh that’s heavy. Come on, Paddington. Put your back into it. He finally manages to PULL THE SACK OFF THE SHELF, but it pulls all the other sacks with it, BURYING HIM COMPLETELY Knuckles begrudgingly goes over and with one hand lifts a enormous sack to reveal Paddington underneath. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) These sacks are awfully heavy.  Post Additional Photography Draft 2 - 06.08.17 52.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Take them one at a time, then.

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Right! One at a-- Knuckles drops the sack of oranges back on top of him. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) --time. Knuckles goes back to his paper, hoping for peace. But behind him, Paddington carries a SINGLE ORANGE from t shelf to the counter, padding on the floor as he goes. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) One juicy orange. He walks back to the shelf. And returns with another oran PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Two juicy oranges. Then back and forth once more. PADDINGTON (CONT’D) Three juicy oranges. Four--

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: Now what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
dialogues.text: Taking them one at a time. Knuckles flies into a rage.

dialogues.speaker: KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: One SACK at a time!

dialogues.speaker: PADDINGTON
